message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has HIV-infection but the mutation prevents entry of HIV into macrophages, suggesting a mutation in the CCR5 protein. Gp120 is used by HIV to enter CD4 positive T-cells, and CD4 is the primary receptor for HIV entry. ICAM-1 is involved in the binding of leukocytes to endothelial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has long-standing HIV infection and refused antiretroviral medication, thus indicating a weakened immune system. The elevated beta-d-glucan suggests an opportunistic fungal infection, which is common in HIV patients. The mutation preventing entry of HIV into macrophages indicates a mutation in CCR5, a protein on the surface of macrophages that HIV uses to enter cells. This mutation provides some protection against HIV infection but increases susceptibility to certain opportunistic infections.

The fact that the patient has been HIV-positive for 25 years but has never had symptoms suggests that there is a mutation that prevents entry of HIV into macrophages. The protein that is most commonly associated with this mutation is CCR5. Gp120 and CD4 are both involved in viral entry into the host cells, but they are not affected by this particular mutation. ICAM-1 is a molecule that is involved in leukocyte adhesion and is not directly involved in HIV infection.
